conversation.content: Um, we're getting an emergency call here and, [confused], I need everyone listening to stay calm while we, well, [anxious], figure out what's happening because, er, this isn't our usual late-night programming.

[shaky voice] I'm trapped in the municipal tunnel system under Fifth Street and, um, [crying while speaking], the water's rising faster than I thought it would, I mean, [desperate], I called 911 but they said twenty minutes and I don't think I have that long. [gasp]
Sir, listen to my voice and focus on, [warm], breathing slowly because panic will only make things, [empathetically], worse and we're going to get through this together right now.
[whispering] Um, I can't, well, swim.
[very quietly] Er, okay, um, okay.
The emergency valve I was fixing broke completely and now, [frustrated], the main water line is flooding everything down here and, [trembling], I can already feel it at my chest. [cough]
Is there any equipment down there you can, [quickly], stand on to buy yourself more time while, [passionately], help arrives because every inch counts right now. [pause]
[loudly] There's a pipe assembly platform about, [hesitantly], ten feet away but I'd have to go underwater to reach it.
Um, you said you can't swim but, well, [stern], can you hold your breath and pull yourself along the pipes, I mean, hand over hand?
[relieved] The pipes run along the ceiling and they're, [animated], bolted every three feet so maybe, [slowly], I could use them like monkey bars if I time it right. [deep breath]
Um, that's perfect and, er, [confidently], I'm going to count you through it because, well, [excited], you're stronger than you think and, I mean, you work with your hands every day.
My kids don't even know I'm, [sad], working overtime tonight because I wanted to surprise them with, [bitter], Christmas presents they actually asked for this year.

[wholehearted] Well, you're going to give them those presents yourself and, um, [sincerely], tell them this story when they're older because, I mean, [cheerful], you're about to be their hero. [laugh]
Um, the water's at my neck now and, well, [terrified], I can hear the sirens but they sound so far away and, er, [whispering loudly], I'm scared of the dark water.
[softly] Close your eyes and picture your kids' faces when, [gently], they open those presents because that's what's waiting for you, [lovingly], on the other side of ten feet of pipe.

I can see the platform now and the water's actually, [surprised], pushing me up toward the pipes and, [determined], maybe this crazy plan will work after all and, [grateful], thank you for not letting me give up. [gasp softly]

[proud] Take three deep breaths with me right now, [calm], then on the count of three you're going to, [encouraging], pull yourself across those pipes like your life depends on it, [firm], because it does. [exhale]

[shouting] I made it to the platform and, um, [exhausted], the rescue team just broke through the access hatch and, well, [crying], I can see their lights coming down and, I mean, [joyful], I'm going home. [cry]
Um, you did that yourself and, well, [melting], I've never been prouder of a stranger in my life than, er, [emotional], I am of you right now.
[grateful] When I get out of here I'm coming to, [friendly], shake your hand because you saved my life tonight by, [tearful], just being there when I needed someone most.

scenario: A late-night radio host takes an emergency call-in from a pipe fitter who's trapped in a flooded underground tunnel system while working alone on overtime repairs.
